prior_works.title: Optimal Auction Design
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the canonical characterization and benchmarks for optimal revenue in single-item auctions, against which posted-pricing performance and sample-complexity guarantees are calibrated.

prior_works.title: Multi-parameter Mechanism Design and Sequential Posted Pricing
prior_works.authors: Shuchi Chawla, Jason D. Hartline, David L. Malec, Balasubramanian Sivan
prior_works.role: Defines the mechanism class and structural insights
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces and analyzes sequential posted pricing as a practical alternative to complex auctions, establishing the mechanism class whose near-optimal prices this paper learns from samples.

prior_works.title: Revenue Maximization with a Single Sample
prior_works.authors: Soraya Dhangwatnotai, Tim Roughgarden, Qiqi Yan
prior_works.role: Early sample-based pricing for single-item auctions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Shows that extremely limited samples can suffice for near-optimal anonymous posted pricing under i.i.d. regular distributions, directly motivating fine-grained sample-complexity questions for posted prices.

prior_works.title: The Sample Complexity of Revenue Maximization
prior_works.role: General sample-complexity framework and lower-bound techniques
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Develops upper and lower bounds for learning revenue-maximizing auctions from samples, whose techniques and benchmark paradigms inform the matching upper/lower bounds established here for posted pricing.

prior_works.title: On the Pseudo-dimension of Nearly Optimal Auctions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides uniform-convergence and pseudo-dimension tools to bound sample complexity of classes of simple auctions, enabling principled upper bounds for learning posted-price policies.

prior_works.title: Comparison of threshold stop rules and maximum for independent nonnegative random variables
prior_works.role: Structural benchmark for welfare via prophet inequalities
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes threshold policies for maximizing welfare with independent draws, underpinning the structure of welfare-optimal posted-price rules whose sample complexity this paper analyzes.

prior_works.title: Full extraction of the surplus in Bayesian and dominant-strategy auctions
prior_works.role: Core insight on correlation in bidder values
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Shows the dramatic power of correlation in auctions, motivating the paper’s separate treatment and distinct sample-complexity bounds for correlated versus independent bidder distributions.

synthesis_narrative: The paper studies how many samples are necessary and sufficient to learn near-optimal sequential posted prices for a single item, across revenue vs. welfare objectives and independent vs. correlated valuations, and it delivers matching upper and lower bounds. Myerson’s optimal auction design provides the canonical revenue benchmark and informs comparisons between posted pricing and optimal auctions. Chawla–Hartline–Malec–Sivan established sequential posted pricing as a central, implementable mechanism class, anchoring the specific policy family whose parameters (prices and ordering) the present work must learn. Dhangwatnotai–Roughgarden–Yan demonstrated that minimal samples can already yield strong revenue via posted prices in i.i.d. settings, motivating sharp, distribution-agnostic sample-complexity characterizations for posted pricing beyond single-sample heuristics. Cole–Roughgarden developed a general framework for auction learning, including lower-bound constructions and uniform-convergence style upper bounds, which this paper tailors to the posted-pricing class to obtain tight rates. Morgenstern–Roughgarden introduced pseudo-dimension methods for simple auctions, providing the learning-theoretic machinery to control sample complexity of parametric mechanism classes such as posted prices. For welfare, Samuel-Cahn’s prophet inequality identifies threshold structures that map naturally to posted prices, guiding the learning targets and concentration analyses. Finally, Crémer–McLean’s insights on correlation highlight that correlated bidders can change identifiability and achievable performance, justifying the paper’s distinct bounds and techniques in the correlated case. Together, these works furnish the mechanism class, benchmarks, structural targets, and learning-theoretic tools that directly enable the paper’s tight sample-complexity characterizations.
